GameDBLocalizedString.Text: Grants extra <color=SOTS_COLOR_RED>Melee Damage</color> to ranged units.
Are they too close for your fancy railgun?\nGrab a knife and stab, stab, stabity-stab!
When locked on target, it's any gunner's best friend, but for the love of God, do not touch the automatic aim option unless you want to play Solitare tonight.
This old trinket greatly improves the <color=SOTS_COLOR_GOLD>Morale</color> of your troops for some reason.
In the Solar system, a Medal of Honor meant an A-class citizenship. In the Siren system, there is no material value behind it, only the respect gained through the blood and pain of the battlefield.
No distance penalties for ranged attacks.

The phrase high-tech is overused. To be truthful, this is late 23rd-century, moderate-level tech. Like 50 years old, third-world, Cold-war stock inherited by a local insurgency level of tech. But still, brutally effective.

While a ton of tech is banned in the Solar system, the Siren system is a frontier without speeding tickets, where blowing six-inch holes through gentlemen clad in military-grade armor is considered fair game.
Energy weapons melt armored enemies.(Bonus for Soldier, Beholder,The Bright One, The Blazing One, Zieregal and High Zieregal.)

Understanding the crystal-based technology of the Primals is beyond even the most skillful Tumori shaman. Most consider it straight-up magic. But tell me, when has a lack of knowledge ever prevented using an unknown phenomenon as a weapon?
Second skin for your units (assuming they have one in the first place)
Tumori biomancy at its finest form. A small stratum of cells impregnated the membrane with zirconium dioxide. Undisguisable by the immune system or even repair nanobots.
If it was really smart, it would help you finish college and prevent you from enlisting. That would be a really good way to protect you from bullets. But, here we are. Now give me fifty rookie!
When they run out of ideas, they always glue together something that fires a flame or an electric charge and call it an upgrade. This time the coin showed the "flame side".

Trampled on, torn off, thrown down, spat on, weather-stained. Beaten countless times. But there is always someone who raises it again. It is just a piece of mycelial fabric, but simultaneously it's so much more.

Some say the divine will of the Goddes strengthens the bearer and their army. Others claim that hope and bravery are artificial and something is meddling with your brainwaves. All that's known is that there is no way to measure its influence, but there is certainly some.

Towering walls, strong gates, and enemy cowards shooting you from loopholes instead of facing you mano a mano. All in all, a siege batlle is anything but fun. However, with a proper ram, you can skip the annoying part and get to hammer distance in no time.
